title: Supermarket campaign for healthy eating attracts mixed reviews - Yahoo7
text:
Share Supermarket campaign for healthy eating attracts mixed reviews - Yahoo7 An advertisement for a European supermarket is causing controversy and receiving mixed reviews online, with some accusing the store of "fatshaming." Close Supermarket chain advertisement sparks controversy UP NEXT VIDEO Supermarket chain advertisement sparks controversy. Source: EDEKA/YouTube Supermarket chain advertisement sparks controversy 
The advertisement for German grocery chain Edeka features a story about a boy in a fictitious town which is inhabited by overweight residents. 
In the campaign, reportedly called 'Eatkarus', the seemingly unhappy people are seen eating the same mashed food at each meal. The people in the fictitious town eat the same food at each meal. Source: EDEKA/ YouTube 
The boy spots a bird while eating and tries to fly away himself, holding onto balloons, a kite and making wings.During his attempts to fly he spots a bird eating berries and then changes his diet, losing weight in the process. In the advertisement the boy spots a bird eating berries. Source: EDEKA/YouTube Beautiful but bizarre ad by German supermarket #Edeka - as if a fatshaming troll hijacked a #JohnLewis xmas campaign https://t.co/VGRU7AkhJI — Kenza Bryan (@KenzaBryan) February 19, 2017 
Towards the end of the advertisement the boy, who appears much slimmer, can be seen running with wings he has made, before flying. 
It ends with the phrase "Iss wie der, der du sein willst," which reportedly translates to "Eat like the one you want to be". The boy makes numerous attempts to fly. Source: EDEKA/YouTube At the end of the story the boy appears to be much slimmer after changing his diet. Source: EDEKA/ YouTube 
One Twitter user wrote: "Beautiful but bizarre ad by German supermarket #Edeka - as if a fatshaming troll hijacked a #JohnLewis xmas campaign" 
Another wrote: "German food retailer #Edeka go viral with fatshame video about “#Eatkarus” while selling fattening convenience food." 
However, many thought the ad was effective. 
One said: "Eat like the person you want to become ! Well done #edeka ! Very clever ad." #eatkarus The only negativity I saw in this ad was from the other townspeople. The boy focused on himself and didn't try to change others.
